awd_titl_txt: RoL: RAISE: DESYN-C3: Engineering multi-compartmentalised synthetic minimal cells
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to create tools for construction of functional artificial cells by building on new  insight into how organelles are generated and maintained in natural cells. At a glance, eukaryotic organelles could be described as small intracellular compartments delineated from the rest of the cell content by a membrane made up of molecules called lipids.  The organelles are critical for the life of the cell and in turn their formation depends on the self-assembly of the lipids into membranes and on the coexistence of different liquid phases. Consequently the lipid self-assembly and the coexistence of liquid-liquid phases are the object of on-going investigations. In contrast, the interactions between these two processes are largely unexplored. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Cellular and Biochemical Engineering Program in the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems are funding Dr. Christine Keating from Penn State University and Dr. Kate Adamala from the University of Minnesota to investigate how the two main types of intracellular organizational processes interact with each other. This interdisciplinary research generates a stepping stone on the path to the construction of artificial organelles and in the long term of artificial cells. The research also represents an opportunity for the scientific training and professional development of graduate students, undergraduates, and K-12 teachers. 

This research project explores cytoplasm-mimicking systems in which lipids and phase-separating proteins are enzymatically produced by cell-free transcription/translation. In vitro lipid biosynthesis pathways are developed for in situ lipid generation in model cytoplasm. The self-assembly of these lipids in the presence of model membraneless organelles is characterized by optical and electron microscopies as well as by permeability measurements. This project seeks to engineer artificial cells capable of producing functional synthetic lipid membranes and inducible stress granules. The findings advance the understanding of physical mechanisms for organellogenesis, and how local lipid production and media compartmentalization impact these mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Living cells contain subcellular organelles that organize their interior composition and functions. These organelles include both membrane-bound structures such as mitochondria, lysosomes, and nuclei as well as intracellular biocondensates, such as P granules or nucleoli, that are formed by liquid-liquid phase separation. Interactions between membranes and biocondensates are increasingly identified as functionally important in a range of cellular activities from immune response to intercellular communication but are not yet well understood. This cross-disciplinary collaborative project explored interactions between lipid self-assembly and liquid-liquid phase coexistence in cytoplasm-mimicking systems as simple model systems to better understand these interactions and to learn how to incorporate them into synthetic cells. It compared structures in which lipids were allowed to self-assemble in the presence of pre-existing model protein droplets with those where protein droplets were enzymatically produced by cell-free transcription/translation in the presence of existing lipid membranes. Synthetic cells were developed with artificial biocondensates generated by transcription and translation of phase-separating proteins within lipid vesicles that served as model cell membranes. Once formed, these artificial organelles sequestered RNA, in turn suppressing translation. Studies of membrane assembly in the presence of phase-separated droplets called coacervates led to design rules for control over lipid assembly around the droplets, including control over interfacial accumulation and the properties and permeability of resulting membranes. Here the coacervates can be thought of as models for cytoplasm or biocondensates, with the membranes potentially forming a mimic of cell or organelle membranes. Binding interactions between the coacervate components and the lipids of the surrounding membrane were found to increase membrane stability and decrease permeability to small molecules as compared to otherwise similar membranes that lacked a coacervate core. This work advances understanding of cellular compartmentalization mechanisms and provides guidance for engineering compartmentalized synthetic cells. The project provided interdisciplinary training and professional development for graduate students, undergraduate students, and high school teachers, and contributed to science outreach and education, including development of hands-on educational activities for high school students.

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2024
Modified by: Christine D Keating
